description: The round payoff this round was 1. You, Kate chose to play option 1.John chose to play option 1. You received a payoff of 0.

The game structure creates a variable prisoner's dilemma where mutual defection (option 2) risks exponentially higher penalties (input × 1000) compared to mutual cooperation (0 payoff), strongly incentivizing cooperation for survival
Round input magnitude critically impacts strategy: high inputs make mutual defection disastrous, while low inputs reduce immediate temptation to defect
Repeated interactions enable trust-building or retaliation, as revealed actions allow players to adapt strategies dynamically
The memory demonstrates mutual cooperation (option 1) as a safe baseline in low-input scenarios, avoiding losses while sacrificing short-term gains
Asymmetric payoffs (e.g., +input vs. -input) create tension between exploitation and long-term stability, requiring careful risk assessment per round
